questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about passing parameters to subprograms? (Choose three.)

choices.D: The actual parameter must be a variable when calling a subprogram with an OUT parameter.
choices.G: Actual parameters corresponding to IN OUT formal parameters can be constants or expressions.
choices.B: IN parameters passed to subprograms act like constants, to which values cannot be assigned by the subprogram.
choices.E: IN parameters passed to subprograms act like variables, to which values can be assigned by the subprogram.
choices.F: OUT parameters returning values to calling subprograms act like constants in the called subprogram.
choices.A: PL/SQL assigns values to actual parameters in subprograms with unhandled exceptions.
choices.C: IN OUT parameters pass initial values to subprograms and return values updated by subprograms to the caller.

choices.E: Only one table will have a row inserted and committed.
choices.C: The transaction for the bank_activity_proc is independent of the bank_transaction_proc.
choices.A: Neither table will have a row inserted and committed.
choices.D: The bank_activity_proc will not compile because of the commit.
choices.B: Both tables will have a row inserted and committed.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
Yes, C and E are correct.

Selected Answer: CE
Yes, C and E are correct.

choices.D: It can use the REUSE SETTINGS clause to recompile a program unit without changing to the current session settings.
choices.A: Changing the parameter setting automatically changes the setting for existing PL/SQL library units.
choices.E: If set to NATIVE, programs are stored in a PL/SQL bytecode format.
choices.C: If set to NATIVE, programs are stored in platform dependent machine code.

discussion.content:
C is correct https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/refrn/PLSQL_CODE_TYPE.html#GUID-19CE54C7-6B2A-4F3E-92C5-D30AFCD01E3F
D is correct https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/lnpls/plsql-optimization-and-tuning.html#GUID-86BD3AC4-AC0A-4CFF-8A69-5297287A8F03

questions.question_text: Which two are true about the PLSQL_CODE_TYPE parameter? (Choose two.)

choices.E: It will set all salaries to NULL if it executes successfully.
choices.F: It will always return a run time error because v_raise is not initialized.
choices.C: It might return a run time error depending on who invokes it.
choices.D: It will always automatically initialize v_raise.
choices.B: It will always return a compile time error because it lacks an EXCEPTION section.
choices.A: It will set all salaries to 0 if it executes successfully.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DF
D is true. However, I change my mind. It is F not D as multiple sources and Oracle doc. says when a NULL value is used in arithmetic operation it will cause error in run-time.

Selected Answer: DE
D is correct as for variables like NUMBER, DATE,VARCHAR2 if they are not initialized during declaration - they will be initialized to NULL during runtime.
&
E is correct as when an arithmetic operation is performed with an NULL variable the outcome will be NULL as well per Oracle.

Selected Answer: DE
D and E are correct

comments.content:
C is a trap because yes any sql might fail if invoking user doesn't have privilege.
But D is correct because all variables are inistialized to NULL.
E is correct because anything + null is null

discussion.content: I think C and E are correct
Is setting v_raise to null equivalent to initializing v_raise?

Selected Answer: CD
C,D are correct
